name: Introduction to the Physical Web
description:
An introduction to the Physical Web and unlocking exciting new ways to interact with the Web.

The Physical Web is an effort to extend the core superpower of the web - the URL - to everyday physical objects. The core premise is that you should be able to walk up to any “smart” physical object (e.g. a vending machine, a poster, a toy, a bus stop, a rental car) and interact with it without first downloading an app. The user experience of smart objects should be much like links in a web browser: i.e., just tap and use.

At its base, the Physical Web is a discovery service: a smart object broadcasts relevant URLs that any nearby device can receive.

name: Google Cloud Training (CP100A): Call for Interest
description:
CALL FOR INTEREST: 

Please fill out this form if you are interested in being considered for a spot on the Google Cloud Platform Fundamentals training event 
http://bit.ly/gdgny-gcptraining-mar2016

ABOUT CP100A TRAINING

The Google Cloud Team has offered to do an all-day training session on Cloud fundamentals for a very small invited group of people (30) next week. 

This is based on the CP100a course and similar to the event we ran in GDG New York last year.

It is a rare opportunity to not just get hands-on coding experience with Cloud technologies, but to meet and learn from key Google developer advocates in that area. 

The training is free but because seats are limited and we can only extend invites to a few folks. If you are interested in attending (and will guarantee to attend the all day event)please fill in the CALL FOR INTEREST form above.

If you are selected to attend you will receive a notification on this by Monday next week.

name: The Path to Success - Women Techmakers 2016
description:
In honor of International Women's Day, we are joining GDGs worldwide to host a Women Techmakers event in the Bronx Innovation Lab.  This is a joint event with Bronx Tech Meetup.

Join us for an evening of networking, talks and Q&A panels with Google Experts, IBM Professionals, Entrepreneurs, and College Students who started their careers in the Bronx.

Our event has been listed as one of the best things to do in NYC and Best NYC Startup & Corporate events for April. 

More importantly, it is a great way to make connections that we hope will serve to drive new collaborations and conversations. We are collaborating on this event with BronxTech to bring the Bronx together. 

The theme of the event is "The Path to Success"

Note: Men are strongly encouraged to join, attend and participate, showing their support and enthusiasm for all people regardless of gender race or creed.

name: DevFest Bronx
description:
Come help us celebrate and learn about Firebase and Progressive Web Apps (PWA).

Progressive Web Applications take advantage of new technologies to bring the best of mobile sites and native applications to users. They're reliable, fast, and engaging.

Firebase is a unified app platform for Android, iOS and web development. Firebase provides
the tools to develop your app, acquire and engage users, and monetize your app. There are 15
features within Firebase that work across iOS, Android and web. These features work
seamlessly together for an intuitive and powerful developer experience.

9:30am    Registration Opens

10:00am  Keynote - From Newbies to Ninjas: Our Stories

2:00pm    Using Firebase to track users

2:45pm     Break

3:00pm    What's the latest on machine learning

name: Progressive Web Apps, Chromebooks Full Stack Web Dev
description:
Join us for the last GDG Bronx Meetup of 2016! 

We will have a special guest speaker joining us all the way from Seattle Washington for this meetup!

Guest Speaker: Clive Boulton - Seattle Google Developer Group Lead Organizer, Ex Dev Director, Now Full Stack Hacker

Agenda
6:00 Doors Open
6:30 Progressive Web Apps (PWA) Hoverboard
7:20 Break 
7:30 Chromebook give me a bash$ - Full Stack web development on Chromebooks 
8:30 Doors Close

Bring your laptops, tablets, phone, anything with a chrome browser. These talks are very hands-on and interactive.

2016 in Review: 

We started the year out with Startup Ideas & Pitch Nights .

We made a group trip to Google NYC for Launchpad Day Latino where Hendrix gave a talk on Android.

Next we kept it going back in the Bronx with a fun and productive MVP weekend.

We continued strong with a series of Android Study Jams. You guys created some awesome projects! Go Bronx!

Next we made another group trip to Google NYC for some FREE Google Cloud Training. 

In April we held a Women Techmaker's Event where we had media coverage and guests speakers that included a Council Members, Ted Talk Experts, IBMers, Entrepreneurs, among other up and coming individuals.

In May we partied with Google I/O Extended 2016 while we watched the keynote, absorbed all the knowledge Hendrix shared from his trip to Google I/O in California, and followed Eva in a hands on Firebase codelab.

In June we held another Startup Idea Night before relaxing during the summer break.

In the Fall we had a great DevFest in a Ninja Turtle theme from Newbie to Ninja with Nelmer, Hendrix and Eva covering Firebase, Machine Learning and Intro to PWA.

Interested in sponsoring or speaking at this or future events? 

Please contact the organizers.

name: Hands On with Firebase & Android Things
description:
Come learn about Firebase and all it has to offer with our live demos. 

Come learn about Android Things and how easy it is to develop connected embedded devices using the same Android development tools, and Google APIs that are used on mobile.

Firebase is a unified app platform for Android, iOS and web development. Firebase provides the tools to quickly develop high-quality apps, grow your user base, and earn more money. Firebase is made up of complementary features that you can mix-and-match to fit your needs. There are 15 features within Firebase that work across iOS, Android and web. These features work seamlessly together for an intuitive and powerful developer experience.

Android Things extends the core Android framework with additional APIs provided by the Things Support Library. These APIs allow apps to integrate with new types of hardware not found on mobile devices.

The Android Things platform is also streamlined for single application use. System apps are not present, and your app is launched automatically on startup to immerse your users in the app experience.

name: Mobile Site Certification Study Jam 2017
description:
As you know, web is one of our core technology pillars. A key way of educating our community and spreading know how on key technologies like mobile speed, PWA, AMP and web payments is through the Mobile Site Certification Study Jam.

Today over 50% of web traffic goes to mobile yet unfortunately developers aren’t designing effectively for it. For example 53% of mobile visitors will leave if a page takes more than three seconds to load. The average page takes 19 seconds to load over 3G. Speed is just one part of creating better mobile experiences and best practice has gone a long way past responsive design alone. Are you up to date?

Requirements

You need basic web development skills to take part and it typically it takes 3-4 hours to run through the course materials, followed by a 90 minute multiple choice exam. You can find more details on the course here. It’s possible to do it entirely online alone, but we’d like to run through it together as a group and support each other.

Why do it?

There is more traffic to mobile sites than desktop, yet most sites don’t provide an effective experience for users. Best practice is changing rapidly so what people may have learned a few years ago may not be up to date. For companies and site owners we see better mobile design leading to significant and measurable improvements in customer acquisition, retention and engagement.

https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/bSj1Irl9Aozfs6nfbsV64oXMDMN0sYZOv40sNISWexT2pX8hgYrQugirJaPNVeWrLkwLzHsCJ4NshtEECL7qv7e5Zefnmf2b4qqP8mEvzC17NwDoXKR1rtaq2dwxAYyJr7VwYXKM

description:
On December 1st we will have talks for both the native and the mobile web warriors!

For all of you native Android app developers that have been asking about Kotlin, Jinn will share his knowledge.

For all of you who say "Web! Web! Web!",  Amal sharing her knowledge.

Why Kotlin? 

Speaker: Jinn Kim

A brief overview of Kotlin and how to convince your organization to switch to it. Some of the major language features and some pros and cons of switching will be covered. Also there will be mentions of future developments announced during KotlinConf 2017.

Jinn Kim is a Android developer since v2.3 operating in the New England area. He also has taught multiple Android developer courses based on the Google’s Study Jam. He’s also the lead organizer of the Boston Android Meetup group. Before he started programming Android apps, he worked primarily in .NET web applications. Currently he is working on connected health apps for a large pharmaceutical company. He is left handed.

Hello, it's your Modern Web Platform! Speaker: Amal Hussein @nomadtechie

Amal has recently join Bocoup as a Sr Open Web Engineer where she will work on web platform interoperability and reliability alongside browser engineers from Google's V8, Mozilla's Spidermonkey and Microsoft's Edge teams. 

Amal is a biomedical engineer turned software engineer that has a passion for creating delightful applications that make a difference. She is hyper-technical and enjoys having a deep understanding of optimizations and the ‘whys’ behind best practices and patterns. Amal loves to travel and has been to over 30 countries, and speaks four languages. She is also a co-host on the Web Platform Podcast and a co-organizer of Boston's Google Developer Group.

description:

Lehman College School of Continuing and Professional Studies

BREAKING INTO THE VR|AR INDUSTRY

https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0?ui=2&ik=545e13fed4&attid=0.2&th=160090b6fe05e2f9&view=fimg&rm=160090b6fe05e2f9&sz=w1600-h1000&attbid=ANGjdJ9Pb7QWH2o-9b6n_5U4HFS5H6jrPL0andP-W_qIHRkRHh2V0kyQM0Jina38Fya-XqvsZE9Z8oA2iIwhu1zyOHZ6448_y5duuecU1CQA4ISl9eDhlCsIbrILH_M&disp=emb

Please join us for a panel and demonstrations with industry leaders discussing the opportunities in New York City’s growing virtual and augmented reality industry.

· Justin Hendrix, Executive Director, NYC Media Lab, connects media and technology companies with New York City’s universities to drive digital media innovation and entrepreneurship. The Lab's interests range across disciplines from data science to virtual and augmented reality, and its programs include seed projects with member companies as well as The Combine, which encourages digital media startup formation on the City’s campuses. Previously Hendrix was Vice President, Business Development & Innovation for The Economist. Hendrix holds a BA from the College of William & Mary and an MSc in Technology Commercialization from the McCombs School of Business, University of Texas at Austin. Follow him on Twitter @justinhendrix.

· Jerelyn Rodriguez, Co-Founder and CEO, The Knowledge House (TKH), was honored as one of Forbes’ 30 under 30 in Education in 2016 for her work starting TKH. Previously, she coordinated STEM after-school programming at Beyond Z and was the Bronx Field Director for Reshma Saujani's 2013 campaign for New York City Public Advocate. Jerelyn has spoken on panels at SXSW, Mozilla Fest and NASA. She is on the leadership council for South Bronx Rising Together, a founding Datanaut at NASA, and a board member at the Bronx Business Incubator. Jerelyn has a degree in film studies from Columbia University.

· Hugh McGrory, Founder & CEO, datavized, brings expertise in film production, art, and technology to the world of immersive media. He was a partner at Culture Shock, consulting for clients including The National Film Board of Canada. In 2011 Hugh brought the partners together to create The Andy Warhol Film Digitization Project, featuring over 500 films by Warhol, developed in collaboration with The Moving Picture Company and Technicolor and described in the New York Times as “the largest effort to digitize the work of a single artist in MoMA’s collection. He completed a Nano Imaging Residency with the CINEMA Microscopy Lab at Yale University School of Medicine in 2007.

· Moderated by, Jane MacKillop, Ph.D., Interim Dean, School of Continuing and Professional Studies at Lehman College, has worked in adult education programs in the UK and the US for over thirty years. She was the first director of the Adult Learning Center at Lehman College in 1987 and subsequently led programs for adults at CUNY's Central Office, York College and City College where she founded the Adult and Continuing Education program and was acting dean of the Center for Worker EducationAuthor of several books, white papers and articles on continuing education and workforce development, she has a BA in English literature, a Postgraduate Diploma in English as a Second Language and a Ph.D. in adult education from the University of Sheffield, UK. She serves on the board of the Continuing Education Association of New York State, where she is vice president.

The demonstrations will begin at 5pm and a networking reception will follow the panel discussion.

description:
Let's get together one last time to end 2017 with a '!'

JUST IN TIME PRICING

LAST MINUTE RSVP

Note: There is a small Transaction Fee ( https://www.meetup.com/help/article/608776 ) when paying via meetup. If you want to save the $1-2 dollar fee you can come find me in person before the 15th to RSVP, or send payment via paypal / google wallet.
Send a message to Eva Sofianos if additional details are needed on where to send payment.

Dinner includes the following:
Choice of Entree (Chicken/Steak/Pork), salad, rice&beans, sweet & green plantains, plus beverage (Soda/Coffee)

Please bring ID if you plan to purchase an alcoholic beverage from the bar.

NOTE:
RSVP of YES doesn't guarantee a seat if payment is not sent prior to the event.

2017 - Year in Review:

It was a full year of learning, exploring and implementing new technologies.

We started the year with Tensorflow followed CloudNext.

Then we spent a night exploring Firebase and Google Maps.

In June, we had a great time with Google I/O Extended where we shared knowledge and explored new technologies.

We tried out developing for the Google Assistant, using Actions on Google, Api.ai (now renamed to Dialogflow), and Machine Learning with TensorFlow.

We learned a little about using Kotlin for Android development.

We had fun with the Raspberry Pis and Android Things codelabs.

By September we even gave Swift a whirl to explore iOS native app development.

In October we got together for the DevFest and learned a lot about the Google Assistant, Voice User Interface (VUI), Android Things and Security Robots, Geohashing, Firebase, and Design techniques.

In November we had a very productive Mobile Web Certification Study Jam.

Half of the participants have already taken the exam and gotten certified! WOOHOO!

In December we had a meetup covering native Android app development using Kotlin, as well as mobile web app development.

We look forward to another great year with everyone in 2018!

name: TensorFlow DevSummit Viewing Party

venue.name: Lehman College Gillet Hall Room 231
venue.address_1: Gillet Hall, 250 Bedford Park Blvd W

description:
As the world is going towards to Machine Learning systems, here is a good opportunity learn as a community.

TensorFlow Dev Summit brings together a diverse mix of machine learning users from around the world for a full day of highly technical talks, demos, and conversation with the TensorFlow team and community.

About TensorFlow TensorFlow™ is an open source software library for numerical computation using data flow graphs. Nodes in the graph represent mathematical operations, while the graph edges represent the multidimensional data arrays (tensors) communicated between them. The flexible architecture allows you to deploy computation to one or more CPUs or GPUs in a desktop, server, or mobile device with a single API. TensorFlow was originally developed by researchers and engineers working on the Google Brain Team within Google's Machine Intelligence research organization for the purposes of conducting machine learning and deep neural networks research, but the system is general enough to be applicable in a wide variety of other domains as well.

The TensorFlow DevSummit is happening in Mountain View on March 30.

https://www.tensorflow.org/dev-summit

Let's hangout and view it together as we learn what's new and break into discussions.

name: Build Conversational Experiences with Actions  on Google
description:
We have 2 excellent guest speakers joining us to share their knowledge on VUI Design and Development.

Jonathan Bloom (Googler)
and
Allen Firstenberg (Google Developer Expert)

Jonathan Bloom is a Voice User Interface Designer working on Google Assistant. Before Google, he worked as UX Research Lead and Voice User Interface Designer for Jibo, the social robotics company. He also spent time as Senior Voice User Interface Manager for Nuance Communications, where he sat on Nuance’s Innovation Steering Committee. He has designed both graphic and speech interfaces for social robots, IVR’s, dictation software, automotive, and mobile applications. Jon lives in New Jersey and works out of Google's New York office. He holds a Ph.D. in Cognitive Psychology from the New School Graduate Faculty. Jon is also a husband, father of two, self-published fiction author, black belt in Isshinryu karate, and a lousy bass player in a "dad band

By day, Allen is a professional software developer and consultant, helping clients understand how they can use technology to make their work easier and their customers happier. But his not-so-secret identity is as a Google Developer Expert for the Assistant - helping developers make awesome Actions by creating new tools, such as the multivocal library, answering questions on Stack Overflow, and doing presentations... kinda like this one. In his lack of spare time he likes photography and science fiction.

Join us for an overview and discussion on how to plan, design and build an Assistant app followed by and code labs where we'll build an Assistant App together.

If you have an app you are working on and would like to share it, or you would like to sponsor the event, please contact the organizers.

• What to bring - Laptop, charger
• Important to know - No prerequisite knowledge
• What to do - Join us for a fun night and build an Assistant App

THIS IS A 2-DAY HACKATHON WHICH WILL RESUME THE NEXT DAY AND CONTINUE TO THE END OF I/O EXTENDED

AGENDA
6:00 Welcome Hendrix Tavarez, Eva Sofianos
6:30 Jonathan Bloom (Googler) - Designing Exceptional Conversations
6:45 Break
7:00 Allen Firstenberg (Google Developer Expert) - Take Action! Building for the Google Assistant
7:45 Break
8:00 HACKING BEGINS! - Build App for Google Assistant
9/9:30 Doors Close
Winners selected next day (Saturday during I/O Extended)
Best App Wins a Prize!!! (4pm Saturday end of I/O Extended)

Jonathan Bloom: Designing Exceptional Conversations

Good design is not just about making products that look and sound good. It’s about making products that people find useful and usable. This is as much the case for the new age of voice-first products as it is for products with more traditional interfaces. In this talk, we’ll discuss what Conversation Design is, and the steps you can easily take to optimize the conversations your customers have with your products.

Allen Firstenberg: Take Action! Building for the Google Assistant

Now that you know what a good conversation sounds like, Allen will discuss how to turn this into a great Action. Using tools such as Dialogflow and the Actions on Google library, you'll learn what you need to know to start developing your first Action for the Google Assistant. Afterwards, you'll be able to put this into practice with the Codelabs, and then build (and publish!) your first Action.

THIS IS A 2-DAY HACKATHON WHICH WILL RESUME THE NEXT DAY AND CONTINUE TO THE END OF I/O EXTENDED

Build an Assistant App for an opportunity to get invited to the Google Assistant community program: that offers a shirt + 200 USD cloud credit every month for a year + much more !

Join other graph hackers for a fun day of building applications featuring Neo4j's great integrations with popular technologies (aka Buzzwords)!

**Agenda:**

Workshop (Optional): 9am-10am (includes breakfast)
GraphHack: 10:00am-3:00pm (includes lunch)
10:00 - 10:30 - teams form
10:30 - 11:00 - presentation / kickoff
11:00 - 3:00 - hacking
Presentations: 3:00pm-4:00pm
GraphHack cocktail hour: 4:00pm

This year we thought it would be fun to highlight many of the useful Neo4j integrations with other technologies in a “Buzzword BINGO” format. This means that teams will be building applications using Neo4j and other technologies listed on their BINGO cards. (see pic) . Each team must make a BINGO (four in row vertically, horizontally, or diagonally) for a valid hackathon submission.

Not currently a graph hacker, or want to learn more? Come early (9am-10am) for a hands on workshop covering an intro to Neo4j and an overview of many of our popular "buzzwords" - also known as technology integrations that make building applications with Neo4j easier :-)

You'll need to bring a laptop that can be used for development and have Neo4j installed.

**Steps:**

0. (optional) Intro workshop. Come to the 1 hour intro to Neo4j workshop.

1. Choose your team. >
Have a team already? Register your team in advance here https://hackdash.org/dashboards/graphbuzz . Don't have a team? Don't worry! We'll be forming teams onsite. Bring an idea for a cool project and find others who want to hack on it with you. Don't have an idea? Watch others pitch ideas and find a fun project you want to work on

2. Choose your bingo card. Find a BINGO option of neo4j buzzwords. Your submission must make a BINGO using the buzzwords on the card.

3. Present! Present your graph hack.

4. Win! Our esteemed panel of judges will be awarding team prizes.

**Rules:**

You must join a team . (it's OK to come alone, meet new friends, etc)

You must present at the end of the day for a chance to win

Please include a slide or diagram that shows the different “Buzzwords”(integrations) your team used

A valid submission should use a combination of technologies listed on their bingo card that make a bingo (4 in a row vertically, horizontally, or diagonally)

You must register your team on the HackDash board https://hackdash.org/dashboards/graphbuzz so we can keep track of your team

Please include the buzzwords used on HackDash

(this card is only an example)

**Prizes**

Airpods

Echo Show

Nest Camera

BB8 Droid

Drones

Google Home

Echo Dot

And more!

**Categories**

Most complete application

Best use of cypher

Most buzzwords used

Best Fully Functional Application

**FAQ**

> Any prerequisites needed for the event?
You will need a laptop and power cord. Ideal that you have Neo4j installed. https://neo4j.com/download/ If not familiar with Neo4j, its suggested that you attend the 9am workshop.
To download Neo4j: neo4j.com/download or check out neo4jsandbox.com for free hosted neo4j suitable for development

> I don't know anyone... can I come alone?
Yes! Plenty of people come alone, meet new friends, and form a team on-site!

> Where do I sign up?
To get an accurate count of attendees and to avoid any duplicates, we ask everyone to please register here: http://bit.ly/graphhack2018

If you have any other questions, don't hesitate to ask in the comments!

name: Google Cloud Next '18 Extended Bronx - Partnership - GDG Cloud NYC & GDG Bronx
description:
Join us in the Bronx for Cloud Next '18 Extended hosted at the beautiful Lehman College campus.

We'll be partnering with GDG Cloud NYC to bring the full experience of Cloud Next '18 to all those who join us on Saturday September 29th.

Google Cloud Next ’18 is a huge annual conference.
This year it will be held July 24–26, 2018 at the Moscone Center in San Francisco where the leading minds in cloud will take the stage to inspire, educate, and power the cloud forward in real time.

Working with GDG Cloud NYC we plan to bring as much of the content, and as many of the leading minds as we can to the Bronx to share their knowledge and experience so we can all build great things and push technology forward together.

Speakers:

Alex Castillo:
Alex is a Co-founder at Neurosity, a neurotechnology company reimagining brain-computer interfaces. He is passionate about the human brain, and how we can use it to power next-generation apps. As a Google Developer Expert, Alex has contributed to the open source community with a focus on web technologies and neurotech.

Angel Rivera:
Angel started his career as an US Air Force Space Systems Operations specialist in Cape Canaveral AF Station where he discovered his passion for technology and software development. He has extensive experience in the private, public and military sectors and his technical experience includes military/space lift operations, software engineering, SRE/DevOPs engineering. He also has a wealth of experience in defense and federal sectors such as contracting, information systems security and management.
Angel’s passions are positive disruption, learning, teaching, mentoring but most of all inspiring all forms of technologists & building awesome tech communities.

Anu Srivastava:
Anu advocates for G Suite developers at Google in New York. She previously worked as a software engineer on Android and developer infrastructure services in the California bay area. She participates in recruiting for computer science interns and new graduates. In her freetime, she performs with her dance company.

Grant Timmerman:
Grant is a developer platform engineer at Google where he leads open source for G Suite APIs. He loves Node, GitHub, and plays the alto saxophone in his spare time.

Jamil Gafur:
Jamil is a Post Bachelor Researcher at Los Alamos national lab. He previously worked there as a summer student for two years while pursuing his Bachelors Degree in Computer Science. His Study Duck continues to accompany him in all his endeavors. Jamil and Study Duck are currently in the process of applying for graduate school.

Joseph Lowery:
Joseph Lowery is a Google Cloud Training Architect at Linux Academy. His courses include Google Cloud Essentials and Google App Engine Deep Dive. He's currently working on the Google Kubernetes Engine Deep Dive course, to be released later this fall. Joe's books about the web and web-building tools are international bestsellers, having sold over 400,000 copies worldwide in eleven different languages. He's also the author of a middle-grade novel of Rafe Rebellius and the Clash of the Genres about a young skateboarding boy who jumps in and out of books. Joe is also a skateboarder, but only in his mind.

AGENDA:
10:00AM Doors Open
10:30AM Google Cloud Next’18 - Overview (video recap )
11:00AM Angel Rivera - Building CI/CD Pipelines with CircleCI & Docker
12:00PM Lunch & Networking
12:45PM Jamil Gafur - Parallelism & High Perf Computing for Dengue(VC)
1:00PM Alex Castillo - Mind-controlling the Web
2:00PM Joseph Lowery - Google Kubernetes Engine: Now & Next
3:00PM Grant Timmerman & Anu Srivastava - All About Apps Script
4:00PM Closing Ceremony followed by Clean Up
5:00PM Doors Close
Codelabs Open at 1pm Track2

CALL FOR PAPERS: http://bit.ly/next18bronx-cfp

CALL FOR SPONSORS:
Please reach out to the organizers to discuss sponsorship opportunities

name: Flutter Study Jam 1st of 3 sessions

venue.name: Lehman College Gillet Hall Room 231
venue.address_1: Gillet Hall, 250 Bedford Park Blvd W

description:
Join us for the Flutter Study Jam Sessions!
Fun, Food, Learning, Badge Earning!

WHAT?
Flutter Study Jams are Community-run study groups based on the Flutter Udacity Course. Participants learn how to use Flutter to develop high-quality, interactive mobile applications for iOS and Android devices.

WHY?
Study Jams are a great opportunity to bring members of your community together to learn Flutter in person and support them to complete the course. Everyone, who completes the course will get a Google-offered Study Jam completion certificate and a profile badge.

WHO?
Flutter Study Jam is suited best for: 1) those just getting started with mobile app development 2) those with programming experience on other mobile app frameworks.

HOW LONG?
3 in-person sessions to cover 7 hours long Udacity course.
What is the end result?
Create a Flutter app while completing the course, get a Google-offered Study Jam completion certificate and a profile badge

name: Cloud Study Jam / Machine Learning APIs
description:
Want to get started on the Google Cloud, but don't know where to begin? Join us for our Cloud Study Jam!
Get official Google training, a $55+ value, free of charge. Together we'll work through several Google Cloud labs. You will get hands-on experience with the Cloud Console, Kubernetes, Security, IoT on Cloud, and Machine Learning.
Then after our live session, you will have free access to more labs you can finish at home. Complete all labs in the quest and earn a Google-hosted badge for your online profile, and additional 30 days access to the training platform to compete any labs you want

Bring a laptop and charger (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed. Don’t forget your charger.

Agenda:
6:00pm Welcome! & Free Access to Qwiklabs
7:30pm Break
8:00pm Resume Hands on learning
9:00pm Event Ends. See you again soon!

#CloudStudyJam @gdgbronx
